questions.text: A pharmacological study measures the relationship between drug dosage (x, in micrograms per millilitre) and increase in heart rate (y, in beats per minute). The relationship is plotted on a graph to determine how the heart rate responds to varying dosages of the drug. Analyze the graph and select the equation that best describes the relationship between x and y:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) y=x+10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a simple linear regression equation of the form y=a+bx, y is the dependent variable, x is the independent variable, a is the y-intercept, and b is the slope.

questions.text: Researchers conducted an investigation to examine the history of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccination in a group of children diagnosed with autism compared to a group of children without autism. Which type of study design best describes this research?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Case control study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Case-control study, researchers begin with an outcome (such as a disease or condition) and look retrospectively at past exposures to investigate possible associations.

questions.text: Match the following national institutes with their corresponding locations: National Tuberculosis Institute (NTI) National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI) National Institute of Virology (NIV) National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) Pune Hyderabad Nagpur Bengaluru
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NTI is in Bengaluru. NEERI is in Nagpur. NIV is in Pune. NIN is in Hyderabad.
  • ➤ NTI is in Bengaluru.
  • ➤ NEERI is in Nagpur.
  • ➤ NIV is in Pune.
  • ➤ NIN is in Hyderabad.

questions.text: Louis Pasteur gave the concept of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Germ theory of disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Louis Pasteur is credited with the Germ Theory of Disease , which established that microorganisms are the cause of many diseases, leading to significant advances in medicine and public health.
  • ➤ Louis Pasteur
  • ➤ Germ Theory of Disease

questions.text: A public health researcher is evaluating different characteristics of health indicators to determine their suitability for a study. Among the following options, which characteristic is not typically considered essential for health indicators?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Affordability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Essential characteristics of health indicators include validity, reliability, feasibility, sensitivity, specificity, and relevance, but affordability is not a core requirement.
  • ➤ affordability

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits her family physician for advice on preventing obesity. The physician discusses various dietary modifications that can help in the primary prevention of obesity. Which of the following dietary modifications is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High fiber diet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the primary prevention of obesity, a high-fiber diet is beneficial as it aids in satiety, calorie control, and digestive health. Fiber intake should be emphasized over high-protein or high-cholesterol diets, which are not as effective for weight management in general prevention strategies.
  • ➤ high-fiber diet

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with a chronic illness. Understanding the sequence of health events can help in planning his treatment and care. Which of the following sequences represents the most logical progression of health-related events?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequence of health-related events: Disease leads to Impairment , which may cause Disability , and ultimately result in a Handicap . This progression highlights the impact of a chronic illness from the onset of disease to its social consequences.
  • ➤ Disease
  • ➤ Impairment
  • ➤ Disability
  • ➤ Handicap

questions.text: Spectacles represents which level of prevention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tertiary (Disability limitation & Rehabilitation)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spectacles represent tertiary prevention by providing disability limitation and rehabilitation , as they help individuals with refractive errors regain functional vision without curing the underlying issue.
  • ➤ tertiary prevention
  • ➤ disability limitation and rehabilitation

questions.text: An epidemiologist is investigating the characteristics of different types of epidemics. Which of the following is true about continuous common source epidemics?

options.label: B
options.text: Duration more than one incubation period

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid rise and fall of epidemic curve

questions.correct_answer: B. Duration more than one incubation period
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Duration more than one incubation period

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Continuous common source epidemic , exposure lasts over multiple incubation periods, resulting in a prolonged duration with a gradual rise and fall of cases, sometimes with secondary waves. This differs from single-exposure epidemics that have a rapid rise and fall within a single incubation period.
  • ➤ Continuous common source epidemic

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched vaccine strain?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Covishield – NIV-2020-770

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct vaccine strains associated with specific vaccines:
  • ➤ Covishield does not use a viral strain like "NIV-2020-770"; instead, it uses a chimpanzee adenovirus vector. The "NIV-2020-770" strain is specific to Covaxin, an inactivated COVID-19 vaccine developed by Bharat Biotech.
  • ➤ Covishield does not use a viral strain like "NIV-2020-770"; instead, it uses a chimpanzee adenovirus vector.
  • ➤ The "NIV-2020-770" strain is specific to Covaxin, an inactivated COVID-19 vaccine developed by Bharat Biotech.

questions.text: A study reveals that the incidence rate of a certain disease is five times greater in women than in men, yet the prevalence rates show no significant difference between the sexes. Which of the following is the most plausible explanation for this observation?

options.label: A
options.text: The case fatality rate for this disease is lower in women

options.label: B
options.text: The case fatality rate for this disease is higher in women

options.label: C
options.text: The duration of disease is shorter in men

options.label: D
options.text: Risk factors for developing the disease are more common in women

questions.correct_answer: B. The case fatality rate for this disease is higher in women
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The case fatality rate for this disease is higher in women

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If incidence is higher in one group but prevalence remains the same across groups, a shorter disease duration (often due to higher mortality or faster recovery) in the group with higher incidence may explain the observation.

questions.text: A public health researcher analyzes the relationship between alcohol consumption and liver cirrhosis and finds that the attributable risk for liver cirrhosis due to alcohol consumption is 90%. This means that a significant portion of liver cirrhosis cases is directly linked to alcohol consumption. Based on this finding, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers are not associated with alcohol consumption

options.label: B
options.text: 90% of liver cirrhosis cases in the population can be eliminated if alcohol consumption is eliminated

options.label: C
options.text: 90% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers can be eliminated if alcohol consumption is eliminated

options.label: D
options.text: 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in the population can be eliminated if alcohol consumption is eliminated

questions.correct_answer: A. 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers are not associated with alcohol consumption
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10% of liver cirrhosis cases in drinkers are not associated with alcohol consumption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Attributable risk indicates the proportion of disease in the exposed group (drinkers) due to the exposure (alcohol), while population attributable risk represents the proportion of disease in the entire population that could be prevented by eliminating the risk factor.
  • ➤ Attributable risk
  • ➤ population attributable risk

questions.text: A medical researcher is analyzing data from a study investigating the link between a new dietary supplement and heart disease. To ensure accurate results, they must consider the role of confounding factors. Which of the following statements about confounding factors is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is found equally between the study and the control groups

options.label: B
options.text: It is itself a risk factor for the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Confounding can be eliminated by selecting a small group

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated either with the exposure or the disease

questions.correct_answer: B. It is itself a risk factor for the disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is itself a risk factor for the disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A confounding factor is associated with both the exposure and the outcome and serves as an independent risk factor for the outcome, necessitating control measures to avoid bias in study results.

questions.text: In a clinical study, the patients are unaware of whether they are receiving a placebo or an active medication, while the researchers administering the treatments are aware of which drug each patient is receiving. What type of blinding is being used in this study?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Single blinding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In single-blind studies , only the subjects are unaware of their treatment group, helping to minimize subject bias but not investigator or analysis biases.
  • ➤ single-blind studies

questions.text: A researcher is preparing a systematic review to evaluate the effectiveness of various interventions for hypertension. During this process, they follow specific guidelines and methodologies. Which of the following is not a characteristic of a systematic review?

options.label: B
options.text: Search for literature is compulsory using explicit search strategy

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meta-analysis always performed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systematic reviews may or may not include a meta-analysis ; meta-analysis is conducted only when appropriate quantitative synthesis is feasible. Both systematic reviews and meta-analyses are rigorous study designs, but only meta-analyses generate a pooled quantitative result.
  • ➤ Systematic reviews
  • ➤ meta-analysis

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the relationship between a suspected environmental toxin and the development of a specific type of cancer. They note that exposure to the toxin occurs before the cancer is detected. This observation is an example of which of the following epidemiological criteria?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Temporality

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Temporality —where the exposure precedes the outcome—is a core criterion in establishing causation in epidemiology, crucially demonstrated through cohort studies and essential to Hill’s criteria for causal inference.
  • ➤ Temporality

questions.text: In which of the following diseases is the human host considered a dead end?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rabies, tetanus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rabies and Tetanus are examples where humans act as dead-end hosts , meaning they cannot transmit the infection further. This contrasts with diseases like measles, where human-to-human transmission is possible and humans are not dead-end hosts.
  • ➤ Rabies and Tetanus
  • ➤ dead-end hosts

questions.text: In a study examining the relationship between two continuous variables, a correlation coefficient of 1.1 is reported. What does this indicate?
questions.correct_answer: D. Computational mistake in calculating correlation
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Computational mistake in calculating correlation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Correlation coefficients range only from -1 to +1 . Any reported value outside this range indicates a computational mistake in calculating the correlation.
  • ➤ Correlation coefficients
  • ➤ -1 to +1
  • ➤ computational mistake

questions.text: In which of the following condition is live vaccines generally not contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Complement deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complement deficiency does not involve T-cell-mediated immunity, so live vaccines are generally safe in these individuals. Live vaccines are contraindicated in conditions involving T-cell immunodeficiencies, immunocompromised states, and pregnancy.
  • ➤ Complement deficiency

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing the World Health Organization's Strategic Advisory Group of Experts (WHO-SAGE) criteria for human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination in children aged 9-14 years. According to the latest WHO-SAGE recommendations, what is the appropriate dosing schedule for HPV vaccination in this age group?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-2 doses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For HPV vaccination in children aged 9-14 years , the WHO-SAGE recommends 1-2 doses as part of primary prevention.
  • ➤ HPV vaccination in children aged 9-14 years
  • ➤ 1-2 doses

questions.text: A 45-year-old radiology technician presents to the occupational health department for a routine check-up. During the visit, he discusses the safety protocols he follows while working. He mentions a sign that is prominently displayed in his work area, which is depicted in the image. What does this sign indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radiation hazard

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiation hazard symbol and understand its importance in alerting individuals to areas where radiation exposure is possible, as well as the appropriate disposal methods for radioactive materials.
  • ➤ Radiation hazard symbol

questions.text: During a routine check of vaccine storage protocols, a nurse needs to ensure that vaccines are stored at their appropriate temperatures. Which of the following vaccines should be stored in the freezer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The storage requirements for vaccines, with OPV being one of the few vaccines that can be stored in the freezer (-15°C to -25°C), whereas most other vaccines require a cold chain storage of 2°C to 8°C.
  • ➤ cold chain

questions.text: A healthcare worker needs to verify whether a vaccine has been inadvertently frozen, which could affect its efficacy. Which of the following tests is used to identify a vaccine that has been frozen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Shake test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The shake test is specifically designed to assess if certain vaccines (like hepatitis B) have been frozen, which can compromise their efficacy. This test is particularly important for vaccines that are temperature-sensitive.
  • ➤ shake test

questions.text: Which of the following statements about population pyramid is not true?

options.label: D
options.text: Shorter and asymmetric for developing countries

questions.correct_answer: C. Broad base indicate low fertility
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Broad base indicate low fertility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A broad base in a population pyramid indicates high fertility rates typically found in developing countries, while a spindle shape with a smaller base and bulge in the middle is characteristic of developed countries with low fertility.
  • ➤ broad base in a population pyramid indicates high fertility rates

questions.text: A hospital epidemiologist is analyzing data from a long-term cohort study to investigate the risk factors for a specific type of cancer. They decide to use a nested case-control study design instead of a routine case-control study. Which of the following study design issues is avoided by using a nested case-control study?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Temporal association

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nested case-control studies help establish temporal associations between exposure and outcome, a challenge often encountered in traditional case-control studies.
  • ➤ Nested case-control studies help establish temporal associations

questions.text: In a hospital, 10 births were recorded: 5 babies weighed over 2.5 kg and 5 weighed less than 2.5 kg. What does the value 2.5 kg represent in this context?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Median

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The median is the value that separates a data set into two equal halves, particularly in a distribution where data is split evenly on either side of this central point.
  • ➤ median

questions.text: A genetic counselor is explaining the process of genetic screening to a couple who are considering having children. Which of the following statements about genetic screening is true? Screening tests define the risk of passing a genetic disorder Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests Screening requires genetic mapping Usually involve invasive procedures
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genetic screening provides a risk assessment for genetic disorders and often involves invasive procedures when used for prenatal testing. Diagnostic tests, not screening tests, are more accurate for confirming genetic conditions.
  • ➤ Genetic screening provides a risk assessment
  • ➤ invasive procedures

questions.text: Which of the following best defines the 'lead time'?

options.label: A
options.text: Disease onset and first critical diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: Disease onset and first possible point of detection

options.label: C
options.text: First possible point of detection and final critical point

options.label: D
options.text: First possible point of detection and usual time of diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: D. First possible point of detection and usual time of diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) First possible point of detection and usual time of diagnosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ lead time is the period between the earliest possible detection of disease through screening and the usual time of diagnosis without screening, indicating the advantage gained by early detection.
  • ➤ lead time is the period between the earliest possible detection of disease through screening and the usual time of diagnosis

questions.text: A laboratory technician is evaluating the reliability of a new diagnostic test for a specific disease. Which of the following statements best describes the reliability of a test?

options.label: A
options.text: It measures what it is supposed to measure

options.label: B
options.text: It is able to correctly predict the presence of disease

options.label: C
options.text: It is able to correctly exclude the possibility of disease

options.label: D
options.text: It yields the same reading/value when repeated under the same conditions

questions.correct_answer: D. It yields the same reading/value when repeated under the same conditions
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It yields the same reading/value when repeated under the same conditions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reliability (or precision) in diagnostic testing refers to the test’s ability to consistently yield the same result under the same conditions, whereas validity refers to how accurately the test measures the intended variable.
  • ➤ Reliability (or precision) in diagnostic testing refers to the test’s ability to consistently yield the same result

questions.text: Two dermatologists are independently evaluating 100 skin biopsy slides for signs of malignancy. Dermatologist A identifies 40 slides as malignant and 60 as benign. Dermatologist B identifies 50 slides as malignant and 50 as benign. Both dermatologists agree on 30 slides identified as malignant and 40 slides identified as benign. Based on this information, what is the Kappa statistic for the inter-rater agreement between the two dermatologists?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) 0.45

questions.text: A screening test for breast cancer is applied to a population of 1,000 women. The test results show 150 positive cases and 850 negative cases. Among the 150 positive cases, 120 women are confirmed to have breast cancer by a diagnostic test, while 30 women are ruled out. Among the 850 negative cases, 50 women are found to have breast cancer. What is the sensitivity of the screening test?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 70%

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

options.label: A
options.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old female

options.label: B
options.text: Neonatal screening in a newborn for hypothyroidism

options.label: C
options.text: Screening of immigrants in a country

options.label: D
options.text: Urine sugar screening in a 40-year-old male

questions.correct_answer: C. Screening of immigrants in a country
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Screening of immigrants in a country

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prospective screening is used as a preventive measure to protect public health , while prescriptive screening focuses on early disease detection for individual benefit .
  • ➤ Prospective screening is used as a preventive measure to protect public health
  • ➤ prescriptive screening focuses on early disease detection for individual benefit

questions.text: A laboratory technician is tasked with finding the optimal cut-off point for a new diagnostic test to differentiate between positive and negative results. Which of the following methods is most appropriate for determining the threshold for diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Receiver operator characteristic curve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ROC curve is a method for selecting the optimal cut-off point in diagnostic tests by analyzing the relationship between sensitivity and specificity.
  • ➤ ROC curve is a method for selecting the optimal cut-off point

questions.text: A public health official in India is studying the transmission patterns of various infectious diseases. Which of the following organisms is known for endogenous transmission in India?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever is known for endogenous transmission in India, unlike other viruses such as Ebola, yellow fever, and Hendra virus, which do not have indigenous presence or transmission patterns in the country.
  • ➤ Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

questions.text: A virologist is comparing the mortality rates of different viral infections after clinical symptoms have developed. Which of the following diseases has the highest mortality rate once clinical manifestations appear?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rabies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rabies has the highest case fatality rate once clinical symptoms develop , making it almost universally fatal due to its severe impact on the nervous system.
  • ➤ Rabies has the highest case fatality rate once clinical symptoms develop

questions.text: A pediatrician is educating parents about the protection provided by maternal antibodies to newborns. For which of the following diseases do maternal antibodies not provide protective immunity to the neonate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pertussis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pertussis is a disease for which maternal antibodies do not provide immunity to the neonate, unlike other diseases such as diphtheria, tetanus, and polio, where maternal antibodies confer partial protection.
  • ➤ Pertussis is a disease for which maternal antibodies do not provide immunity

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically included in the manifestations of Congenital Rubella Syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intracerebral hemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intracerebral Hemorrhage is not a typical manifestation of Congenital Rubella Syndrome , while the triad of cataract, heart defects, and sensorineural deafness are classic signs.
  • ➤ Intracerebral Hemorrhage is not a typical manifestation of Congenital Rubella Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements about influenza is true?

options.label: D
options.text: All ages and sexes are equally affected

questions.correct_answer: D. All ages and sexes are equally affected
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All ages and sexes are equally affected

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ influenza affects all ages and sexes , with frequent asymptomatic cases and an incubation period of 1-3 days. Pandemics are also relatively common with influenza.
  • ➤ influenza affects all ages and sexes

questions.text: An epidemiologist aims to assess the incidence of tuberculosis (TB) infection in a community. Which of the following methodologies would be most appropriate for this objective?

options.label: A
options.text: Identify all individuals with positive tuberculin test

options.label: B
options.text: Perform sputum examination of chest symptomatics

options.label: C
options.text: Identify new converters to the tuberculin test

options.label: D
options.text: Screen all under-five children with the tuberculin test

questions.correct_answer: C. Identify new converters to the tuberculin test
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Identify new converters to the tuberculin test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracking new converters to the tuberculin test provides an accurate measure of TB infection incidence, reflecting newly acquired infections in a community.
  • ➤ Tracking new converters to the tuberculin test

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. Which of the following serum markers are likely to be seen in their profile? HbsAg + Anti HBs + Anti HBc + HBV DNA +
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic hepatitis B infection typically includes HbsAg, Anti-HBc (IgG), and HBV DNA markers, indicating ongoing infection and active or low viral replication.
  • ➤ Chronic hepatitis B infection
  • ➤ HbsAg, Anti-HBc (IgG), and HBV DNA

questions.text: A public health specialist is discussing the prevention and characteristics of typhoid disease. Which of the following statements are true regarding typhoid?

options.label: A
options.text: For prevention of typhoid, the most important step is immunization

options.label: B
options.text: Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene are more important than immunization

options.label: C
options.text: Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB

options.label: D
options.text: Person-to-person transmission is present in 10% of cases

questions.correct_answer: B. Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene are more important than immunization
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene are more important than immunization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Public health measures—such as safe water supply, proper sanitation, and good hygiene practices—are more effective than immunization alone in preventing typhoid at a population level.

questions.text: A physician is evaluating if a patient has dengue fever. According to the Torniquet test, a positive test is declared if number of petechial spots/ sq inch skin are more than?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 10

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tourniquet test for dengue fever, a positive result is indicated by the presence of more than 10 petechial spots per square inch, confirming increased capillary fragility and aiding in the diagnosis of dengue fever.

questions.text: A global health organization is evaluating indicators for malaria control in a high-burden country. Which of the following best describes the recent transmission?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IPR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infant Parasite Rate (IPR) is the best indicator of recent malaria transmission, as it reflects malaria incidence in infants, who would have acquired the infection in the last 12 months.

questions.text: DEC is known to be most effective against which stage of the filarial parasite?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Microfilariae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is primarily effective against microfilariae in filariasis, making it essential for controlling the transmission of the disease.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child comes to the emergency room after being bitten by a stray dog. The bite was unprovoked and the child's vaccination history is unclear. What is the most appropriate action to take?

options.label: A
options.text: Withhold vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days

options.label: B
options.text: Administer a cell culture-derived rabies vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: Kill the dog and send the brain for analysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer a cell culture-derived rabies vaccine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administer a cell culture-derived rabies vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of unprovoked bites from stray animals with uncertain vaccination histories, immediate post-exposure rabies vaccination is essential to prevent rabies, a fatal disease.

questions.text: In the transmission cycle of Japanese encephalitis, which of the following animals serves as the amplifier host?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pigs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pigs are the amplifier hosts in the transmission cycle of Japanese encephalitis, which increases virus prevalence through mosquito vectors like Culex tritaeniorhynchus .
  • ➤ Culex tritaeniorhynchus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Scrub typhus is not true?

options.label: B
options.text: Adult mite feeds on vertebrate host

questions.correct_answer: B. Adult mite feeds on vertebrate host
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adult mite feeds on vertebrate host

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Scrub typhus, only the larval stage of the mite feeds on vertebrates and transmits the infection; adult mites do not feed on vertebrates.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms does not require a vector for transmission?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Coxiella burnetiid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coxiella burnetii does not require a vector for transmission and can spread through inhalation of aerosols or consumption of unpasteurized milk, unlike other vector-borne organisms such as Rickettsia species and Borrelia recurrentis.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic 4 hours after sustaining a clean wound without laceration. He received a tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccine 10 years ago. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Single dose of TT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with clean, minor wounds who have received tetanus toxoid within the last 10 years, a single booster dose of TT is sufficient to ensure immunity without the need for tetanus immunoglobulin.

questions.text: A public health expert is analyzing the reasons why leprosy has not yet been eradicated. Which of the following is a major contributing factor to the persistence of leprosy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Long incubation period

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The long incubation period of leprosy is the primary challenge in eradication efforts, as it enables prolonged, undetected transmission within populations.

questions.text: Match the STD kit color with the corresponding syndrome:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ White - Genital Ulcer Disease Grey - Urethral/Cervical Discharge Green - Vaginal Discharge Yellow - Lower Abdominal Pain
  • ➤ White - Genital Ulcer Disease
  • ➤ White
  • ➤ Grey - Urethral/Cervical Discharge
  • ➤ Grey
  • ➤ Green - Vaginal Discharge
  • ➤ Green
  • ➤ Yellow - Lower Abdominal Pain
  • ➤ Yellow

questions.text: For which of the following diseases is the iceberg phenomenon not observed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The iceberg phenomenon is not observed in diseases with no carriers or few asymptomatic cases, such as measles, rubella, rabies, tetanus, and pertussis .
  • ➤ measles, rubella, rabies, tetanus, and pertussis

questions.text: A physician is considering the incubation periods of various infectious diseases to determine the appropriate isolation measures. Which of the following diseases has an incubation period of less than 7 days?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cholera

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera has a short incubation period of 1 to 2 days, making it significantly shorter than diseases like measles, leishmaniasis, and mumps, which have incubation periods exceeding 7 days.
  • ➤ Cholera

questions.text: Mrs. Anita wants to start a balanced diet. Which of the following should be advised? Proteins 10-15% of total energy intake Fats 15-30% of total energy intake Carbohydrates 30-45% of total energy intake Fibre intake 200 grams a day
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Balanced diet generally includes 10-15% of energy from proteins, 15-30% from fats, and 50-70% from carbohydrates , with fiber intake recommended at up to 40 grams per day for adults.
  • ➤ 10-15% of energy from proteins, 15-30% from fats, and 50-70% from carbohydrates
  • ➤ up to 40 grams per day

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the relationship between two quantitative variables. Which type of graph should they use to best illustrate this correlation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Scatter diagram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scatter diagram is the appropriate graph for analyzing and visualizing the correlation between two quantitative variables, providing insights into the strength and direction of their relationship.
  • ➤ Scatter diagram

questions.text: A healthcare professional is educating patients about the potential consequences of HPV infection. Which of the following conditions can HPV infection lead to? (Multiple responses) Cervical cancer Anal cancer Oropharyngeal cancer Laryngeal papillomatosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV infection is linked to multiple conditions, including cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal cancers , as well as laryngeal papillomatosis . High-risk HPV strains (e.g., HPV-16 and HPV-18) are often implicated in these malignancies. HPV can also cause genital and anorectal warts and cancers of the vulva and vagina.
  • ➤ cervical, anal, and oropharyngeal cancers
  • ➤ laryngeal papillomatosis

questions.text: Which of the following indices of obesity does not take height into consideration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Corpulence index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Corpulence Index is an obesity index that does not consider height, relying solely on the ratio of actual to desirable weight.
  • ➤ Corpulence Index

questions.text: A public health expert is evaluating various indicators to monitor the trend of tuberculosis (TB) in a community, seeking a measure unaffected by current TB control interventions. Which of the following is the best indicator for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Annual Risk of Infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Annual Risk of Infection (ARI) is the best measure to monitor TB trends independently of control interventions, providing insight into the true transmission rate in a community.
  • ➤ Annual Risk of Infection (ARI)

questions.text: A healthcare policy analyst is reviewing components of the Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn, Child, and Adolescent Health (RMNCH+A) strategy. Which of the following actions is not included in the RMNCH+A approach?

options.label: A
options.text: Linking Maternal health to Reproductive health

options.label: B
options.text: Linking home and community-based services to facility-based care

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Involvement of private organizations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The RMNCH+A strategy is primarily implemented through government health facilities and does not depend on private organizations, though limited private sector involvement occurs in specific schemes like PMSMA.
  • ➤ RMNCH+A strategy
  • ➤ government health facilities

questions.text: A vision care advocate is studying organizations involved in the Vision 2020 initiative, aimed at eliminating avoidable blindness. Which of the following organizations is not part of the Vision 2020 initiative?

options.label: D
options.text: International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) UNICEF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ UNICEF is not part of the Vision 2020 initiative , which focuses on eliminating avoidable blindness through a coalition of organizations led by WHO and IAPB, among others.
  • ➤ UNICEF
  • ➤ Vision 2020 initiative

questions.text: A resident doctor sustains a needlestick injury while drawing blood from an HIV-positive symptomatic patient. What is the best regimen for post-exposure prophylaxis for this resident doctor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For post-exposure prophylaxis in adults following potential HIV exposure, the recommended regimen is Tenofovir, Lamivudine, and Dolutegravir (TLD) .
  • ➤ post-exposure prophylaxis in adults
  • ➤ Tenofovir, Lamivudine, and Dolutegravir (TLD)

questions.text: An urban health program manager is designing an intervention for malaria control in a city. What is the Urban Malaria Scheme primarily based on?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-larval measures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Urban Malaria Scheme primarily focuses on anti-larval measures to control mosquito populations in urban settings, supplemented by anti-adult measures as needed.
  • ➤ Urban Malaria Scheme
  • ➤ anti-larval measures

questions.text: According to the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, which of the following disease is not covered?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The IMNCI guidelines primarily cover measles, malaria, diarrhea, pneumonia, and malnutrition in children under five but do not specifically include anemia.
  • ➤ IMNCI guidelines
  • ➤ measles, malaria, diarrhea, pneumonia, and malnutrition

questions.text: Not true about Leprosy is?

options.label: B
options.text: Cold temp loss is the first sensation loss

options.label: C
options.text: Paucibacillary leprosy does not have nerve involvement

options.label: D
options.text: Multibacillary leprosy duration of follow up is 5 years

questions.correct_answer: C. Paucibacillary leprosy does not have nerve involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paucibacillary leprosy does not have nerve involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In paucibacillary leprosy , nerve involvement can be absent or involve a single nerve. Recognize that multibacillary cases have a longer treatment and follow-up period, while early sensory loss, especially cold sensation, is common in leprosy.
  • ➤ paucibacillary leprosy
  • ➤ multibacillary cases

questions.text: Recommended level of Iodization of salt is?

options.label: A
options.text: Production level: 60 ppm, Consumer level: 30 ppm

options.label: B
options.text: Production level: 45 ppm, Consumer level: 30 ppm

options.label: C
options.text: Production level: 30 ppm, Consumer level: 15 ppm

options.label: D
options.text: Production level: 20 ppm, Consumer level: 10 ppm

questions.correct_answer: C. Production level: 30 ppm, Consumer level: 15 ppm
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Production level: 30 ppm, Consumer level: 15 ppm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommended iodization level for salt is 30 ppm at the production level and 15 ppm at the consumer level, providing adequate iodine intake despite losses during transport and storage.
  • ➤ recommended iodization level for salt

questions.text: In a city with a population of 8000, the crude birth rate is 25 per 1000 people. How many pregnant females are expected in this city?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 220

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When calculating expected pregnancies, always adjust for pregnancy wastage, typically around 10% in public health estimates, for an accurate count of pregnancies based on the crude birth rate.

questions.text: The number of live births per 1000 women aged 15-49 years in a given year is referred to as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) General Fertility Rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is defined as the number of live births per 1000 women of reproductive age (15-49 years) in a specific year.
  • ➤ General Fertility Rate (GFR)
  • ➤ number of live births per 1000 women of reproductive age

questions.text: A national health agency uses a data collection system that combines continuous enumeration with periodic surveys every six months to provide estimates of vital statistics. This system is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sample registration survey

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sample Registration System (SRS) in India provides accurate vital statistics by combining continuous enumeration with biannual surveys , using a unique dual-recording approach for reliability.
  • ➤ Sample Registration System (SRS)
  • ➤ continuous enumeration with biannual surveys
  • ➤ dual-recording approach

questions.text: A new contraceptive method 'X' is being tested by 200 couples over a 1-year period. During this time, 30 women become pregnant despite using the contraceptive 'X'. What is the Pearl Index of 'X'?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 15 per HWY

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pearl Index formula for contraceptive efficacy is critical to calculate, using the formula: (Accidental Pregnancies/Total Months of Exposure)×1200

questions.text: A public health campaign installs hand sanitizer dispensers at public transportation hubs in areas with high rates of influenza transmission. This intervention is an example of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary prevention

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary prevention aims to prevent disease by targeting risk factors and promoting protective measures, as seen in the installation of hand sanitizers to reduce influenza transmission.
  • ➤ Primary prevention
  • ➤ hand sanitizers

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a 2-year-old child who is still breastfeeding is experiencing heavy and irregular menstrual bleeding. Which contraceptive method is most appropriate for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Progestasert

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For breastfeeding women with heavy, irregular menstrual bleeding , progesterone-based methods like Progestasert or progesterone-only pills are recommended, as they do not affect lactation and can aid in regulating menstrual bleeding.
  • ➤ breastfeeding women
  • ➤ heavy, irregular menstrual bleeding
  • ➤ progesterone-based methods
  • ➤ Progestasert

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically used as an emergency contraceptive?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Levonorgestrel intrauterine system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) is intended for regular, long-term contraception, not emergency use.
  • ➤ Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS)

questions.text: A couple, where one partner frequently travels for work and is away for extended periods, needs a reliable contraceptive method for when they reunite. Which method is most suitable for them?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Barrier methods

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For couples who meet occasionally, barrier methods provide reliable, flexible contraception without the need for continuous usage, making them ideal for infrequent reunions.
  • ➤ barrier methods

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy, weighing 60 kg and with a hemoglobin level of 11.5 gm%, visits her healthcare provider for dietary advice. What should be the recommended additional caloric intake for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Additional intake of 350 Kcal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the second trimester of pregnancy , an additional 350 Kcal/day is recommended to meet the increased nutritional demands for maternal and fetal health.
  • ➤ second trimester of pregnancy
  • ➤ 350 Kcal/day

questions.text: In a population, there are 3100 births in a year including 100 still births. Among these, there are 50 neonatal deaths within the first 7 days of life and 100 deaths within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) 50 per 1000 live births

questions.text: A pediatrician is assessing children for severe acute malnutrition (SAM). Which of the following is not a criterion for diagnosing SAM?
questions.correct_answer: B. Weight for age below 3 SD
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Weight for age below 3 SD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weight-for-age is not a criterion for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) , which is assessed by MUAC <115 mm, WFH < -3 SD, bipedal edema , or visible severe wasting .
  • ➤ Weight-for-age
  • ➤ Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)
  • ➤ MUAC <115 mm, WFH < -3 SD, bipedal edema
  • ➤ visible severe wasting

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the contributions and initiatives under the Colombo Plan?

options.label: A
options.text: It focused solely on industrial development, excluding agricultural support.

options.label: B
options.text: AIIMS, New Delhi was established with financial assistance from Canada.

options.label: C
options.text: Canada supplied Cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India.

options.label: D
options.text: The plan did not provide any support for health promotion.

questions.correct_answer: C. Canada supplied Cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Canada supplied Cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Colombo Plan provided Cobalt therapy units from Canada to India’s medical institutions, underscoring its contributions to health promotion and multi-sectoral development in the Asia-Pacific region.
  • ➤ Colombo Plan
  • ➤ Cobalt therapy units from Canada

questions.text: A couple delivers their first child. They belong to which stage of family cycle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the family cycle , the extension stage begins with the birth of the first child and continues through subsequent births until the last child is born.
  • ➤ family cycle
  • ➤ extension stage

questions.text: When calculating the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for a particular nutrient, 2 standard deviations (SD) are not added for which of the following nutrients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Energy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The RDA for energy does not include an additional 2 SD buffer to prevent the risk of excessive energy intake leading to weight gain.
  • ➤ RDA for energy

questions.text: An arrow diagram representing the logical sequence in which events must take place is drawn. It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring the project; allows better communication between various levels and helps furnish timely, updated progress reports. This is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PERT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PERT uses arrow diagrams to sequence project tasks logically and efficiently, aiding in planning, scheduling, and monitoring project progress.
  • ➤ PERT
  • ➤ planning, scheduling, and monitoring

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of bleeding tendency, including hemorrhages and ecchymosis. Deficiency of which vitamin is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, causing bleeding symptoms such as hemorrhages and ecchymosis, characteristic of scurvy.
  • ➤ Vitamin C deficiency
  • ➤ bleeding symptoms

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the risk factors for developing skeletal fluorosis in a community. At what level of fluorine intake does crippling fluorosis typically occur?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) >10 ppm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crippling fluorosis occurs when fluoride intake exceeds 10 ppm , with initial fluoride changes typically seen in the upper central incisors.
  • ➤ Crippling fluorosis
  • ➤ 10 ppm

questions.text: Consumption of raw eggs is associated with a deficiency of which nutrient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Biotin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Biotin deficiency can result from regular consumption of raw eggs due to avidin , which binds biotin and inhibits its absorption.
  • ➤ Biotin deficiency
  • ➤ avidin

questions.text: A food safety inspector is investigating an outbreak of ergotism in a rural area. Which of the following fungi is responsible for producing the toxic alkaloids that cause ergotism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Claviceps purpurea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Claviceps purpurea is the fungal source of ergot alkaloids , which cause ergotism when contaminated grains are consumed.
  • ➤ Claviceps purpurea
  • ➤ ergot alkaloids

questions.text: A sociologist is investigating the impact of various social issues on public health. Which of the following best describes the concept of social pathology?

options.label: A
options.text: Change in disease pattern due to change in lifestyle

options.label: B
options.text: Study of social problems which cause disease in population

options.label: C
options.text: Conflicts arising from new opportunities in transitional societies

options.label: D
options.text: Study of human relationships and behavior

questions.correct_answer: B. Study of social problems which cause disease in population
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Study of social problems which cause disease in population

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Social pathology is the study of social issues and problems that contribute to health challenges within populations, emphasizing how social factors such as poverty, substance abuse, and overcrowding can increase disease risk.
  • ➤ Social pathology
  • ➤ social issues and problems that contribute to health challenges

questions.text: During a public debate, a group of individuals holds a temporary and provisional view on a contentious issue. What is this temporary viewpoint called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Opinion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An opinion is a temporary and provisional view that can change over time, unlike beliefs and attitudes, which are generally more stable.
  • ➤ opinion
  • ➤ temporary and provisional view

questions.text: An environmental scientist is evaluating the quality of water in a local reservoir by considering various chemical parameters. What is the Saturation index used for?

options.label: A
options.text: Used to assess the air quality by measuring concentration of pollutants

options.label: B
options.text: Used to assess the water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH

options.label: C
options.text: Used to assess the soil quality to determine whether it is good for growing crops

options.label: D
options.text: Used to assess the milk quality by estimating the bacterial count in it

questions.correct_answer: B. Used to assess the water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Used to assess the water quality by estimating hardness, total dissolved solids, alkalinity, and pH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Langelier Saturation Index (LSI) assesses water quality in terms of calcium carbonate saturation , helping to predict whether water will cause scaling or corrosion based on parameters like hardness, TDS, alkalinity, pH, and temperature.
  • ➤ Langelier Saturation Index (LSI)
  • ➤ calcium carbonate saturation

questions.text: A microbiologist is identifying bacteria that indicate fecal pollution in water samples. Which of the following bacteria is not typically associated with fecal pollution?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ E. coli, Enterococcus, and Clostridium perfringens are commonly used as indicators of fecal contamination in water , while Staphylococcus is not associated with fecal pollution.
  • ➤ E. coli, Enterococcus, and Clostridium perfringens
  • ➤ fecal contamination in water
  • ➤ Staphylococcus

questions.text: An environmental health specialist is assessing different indicators of air pollution in an industrial area. Which of the following is not an indicator of air pollution?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) McArdle’s index

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ McArdle's index measures sweating rates and is not related to air pollution indicators.

questions.text: An engineer is designing a sewage treatment plant. Which of the following is the not used to measure the strength of sewage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Coliform count

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coliform Count is not used to measure the strength of sewage.

questions.text: The vector shown in the image causes all of the following diseases except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Kyasanur forest disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kyasanur forest disease is caused by a tick and is not associated with the itch mite, which causes scabies.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by louse?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is transmitted by ticks, not by lice.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man had a cardiac pacemaker removed during a recent surgical procedure. As part of the hospital's waste management protocol, into which type of waste container should the discarded pacemaker be placed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blue cardboard box

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metallic implants, such as pacemakers, are disposed of in the blue cardboard box for recycling in hospital waste management.

questions.text: As a Medical Officer in a Primary Health Center (PHC) located in a seismic zone, you are responsible for disaster preparedness. Which of the following actions should you not take?

options.label: A
options.text: Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized quickly during a disaster

options.label: C
options.text: Conduct disaster simulation practices and evaluate the response

options.label: D
options.text: Follow announcements given on loudspeakers without verification

questions.correct_answer: D. Follow announcements given on loudspeakers without verification
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Follow announcements given on loudspeakers without verification

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unverified information, especially in disaster scenarios, should not be followed without confirmation to avoid potential misguidance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who retired 5 years ago after working for decades in a benzene factory presents with fatigue and unexplained bruising. Given his occupational history, which of the following is a likely complication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Blood cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolonged exposure to benzene is a risk factor for blood cancers, particularly leukemia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer presents with chronic respiratory symptoms. He has a history of long-term exposure to moldy hay. Which pneumoconiosis is most likely caused by exposure to Micropolyspora faeni?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Farmer’s lung

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Exposure to Micropolyspora faeni in moldy hay causes Farmer’s lung, a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.text: A geneticist is studying the frequency of a particular allele in a population. This study is based on principles that predict how gene frequencies will be inherited from one generation to the next in an ideal population. Which of the following laws is the geneticist applying?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hardy-Weinberg law

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hardy-Weinberg law predicts the stability of allele frequencies across generations in a large, ideal population.

questions.text: For which of the following purposes is the SPIKES protocol used?

options.label: B
options.text: Communication with patients/attendants regarding bad news

questions.correct_answer: B. Communication with patients/attendants regarding bad news
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Communication with patients/attendants regarding bad news

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SPIKES protocol is used for delivering bad news, especially in sensitive situations like cancer diagnoses.

questions.text: Match each committee with the recommendation they are known for. List A Shrivastava Committee Chadah Committee Kartar Singh Committee Jungalwallah Committee List B Malaria workers to look after family planning work too Integration of health services Led to the creation of Health Guides Led to the creation of Multipurpose Workers (MPW) Which of the following correctly matches List A with List B?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A healthcare manager is conducting an evaluation of a new public health intervention. Which of the following is not considered an essential element of evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Repeatability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Repeatability is not a core element in evaluating public health interventions.
